hints: A genre based on imagination and not fact.
Includes stories about invented characters and events.
The opposite of nonfiction.
A genre based on real events and facts.
Includes biographies, essays, and history books.
The opposite of fiction.
A genre with magical and supernatural elements.
Often includes mythical creatures and alternate worlds.
Examples include 'Lord of the Rings' and 'Harry Potter'.
A genre exploring futuristic concepts and technology.
Often set in outer space or a different time.
Includes 'Dune' and 'Starship Troopers'.
A genre focused on solving a crime or puzzle.
Often features a detective or amateur sleuth.
Popularized by authors like Agatha Christie.
A genre designed to evoke excitement and suspense.
Keeps the reader on the edge of their seat.
Examples include 'The Da Vinci Code'.
A genre intended to frighten and startle the reader.
Often involves supernatural beings or macabre events.
Works by Stephen King are prominent.
A genre focused on love and emotional connection.
Central plot revolves around a relationship.
Can be a subgenre of historical or paranormal fiction.
Set in the past, blending real history with fictional stories.
Characters and events are often products of the author's imagination.
The backdrop is a specific time period.
A genre set in the American frontier during the 19th century.
Often features cowboys, saloons, and gunfights.
A classic example is 'Lonesome Dove'.
The true story of a person's life, written by someone else.
This is a type of nonfiction.
It provides a detailed account of a real person.
The true story of a person's life, written by that person.
A type of nonfiction memoir.
A self-written account of one's life.
A personal account of a specific period or event in one's life.
Focuses on a particular theme or relationship.
More narrowly focused than an autobiography.
A genre of literature that uses rhythm and often rhyme.
It is a form of verse and language.
Often expresses feelings and ideas in a structured way.
A genre written to be performed on stage.
It includes plays, comedies, and tragedies.
Shakespeare is a famous writer in this genre.
A genre targeted at readers between 12 and 18.
Often features a coming-of-age theme.
Examples include 'The Hunger Games' and 'Twilight'.
A genre written and published for people under 12.
Includes picture books and early readers.
This genre often features simplified language.
A narrative genre where an author creates a new, fictional mythology.
J.R.R. Tolkien is a key figure in this genre.
Combines myth and epic elements.
A genre featuring a futuristic, corrupted society.
Often a cautionary tale about a bad future.
Examples include '1984' and 'The Handmaid's Tale'.
A genre featuring an ideal, perfect society.
Often explores social and political ideals.
The opposite of dystopian fiction.
A genre combining fiction, horror, and Romanticism.
Often set in gloomy, ruined castles.
Includes elements of mystery and the supernatural.
A genre that focuses on a protagonist's moral and psychological growth.
A 'coming of age' story.
A German term for a 'novel of education'.
A long, narrative poem about a heroic figure.
Examples include 'The Odyssey' and 'Beowulf'.
Often deals with a nation's founding or a major conflict.
A short poem expressing a single speaker's emotions.
Often features rhyme and meter.
Sonnets and odes are examples.
A genre that uses humor and exaggeration to criticize people or society.
Often aims to provoke social change.
Jonathan Swift's 'A Modest Proposal' is an example.
A story that has a hidden meaning, often moral or political.
Characters and events represent abstract ideas.
'Animal Farm' is a well-known example.
A short story, often with talking animals, that teaches a moral.
Associated with Aesop.
The lesson is usually stated at the end.
A short story used to illustrate a moral or spiritual lesson.
Unlike a fable, it usually features human characters.
Examples are found in the Bible.
A children's story featuring magical elements and fantastic creatures.
Often starts with 'Once upon a time...'.
Associated with the Brothers Grimm and Hans Christian Andersen.
A story passed down through generations by word of mouth.
Often reflects a culture's beliefs and values.
Similar to a myth or legend.
A traditional story about gods or heroes.
Explains natural phenomena or a culture's origins.
Greek and Roman stories are common examples.
A story from the past, believed to be true but not proven.
Often about a hero or a supernatural event.
King Arthur is a famous figure in this genre.
A serious play with an unhappy ending.
The protagonist often suffers due to a flaw or fate.
A famous play by Shakespeare is 'Hamlet'.
A play or story with a light, humorous tone and a happy ending.
A famous playwright is Moli√®re.
The opposite of tragedy.
A genre featuring supernatural beings or phenomena.
Includes stories about ghosts, vampires, and werewolves.
Often a subgenre of romance or urban fantasy.
A subgenre set in a city with magical elements.
The magical world coexists with the modern world.
Examples include 'The Dresden Files'.
A genre that blends fantasy with elements of horror.
Often has a somber, gloomy tone.
Examples include 'Berserk' and some works of Neil Gaiman.
A subgenre set in an entirely fictional world.
Often involves an epic struggle between good and evil.
Think 'The Lord of the Rings'.
A subgenre set in the real world with magical elements.
Magic is a small, subtle part of the story.
The opposite of high fantasy.
A genre of prose fiction about a roguish hero.
The protagonist goes through many adventures.
Examples include 'Don Quixote'.
A novel written as a series of documents.
Can be letters, diary entries, or newspaper clippings.
Mary Shelley's 'Frankenstein' uses this technique.
A subgenre of mystery focused on a professional investigator.
The protagonist works to solve a crime.
Sherlock Holmes is a famous example.
A subgenre of detective fiction with a cynical, tough hero.
Often explores the corrupt side of society.
Associated with authors like Raymond Chandler.
A subgenre characterized by a bleak, pessimistic tone.
Often features a flawed protagonist and a femme fatale.
Often overlaps with detective fiction.
A subgenre of mystery with no graphic violence or sex.
Often set in a small, close-knit community.
The detective is typically an amateur.
A nonfiction genre that details real-life crimes.
It is a popular topic for documentaries and podcasts.
Often covers murder, serial killers, and heists.
A brief work of prose fiction.
Shorter than a novella.
Poe and O. Henry are famous practitioners.
A short novel, longer than a short story.
The length is typically between 17,500 and 40,000 words.
'A Christmas Carol' is a classic example.
A very short story.
The word count is typically under 1,000 words.
A form of microfiction.
A genre that uses literary styles to create factual narratives.
Blends personal experience with factual information.
Includes memoir, essay, and travel writing.
A type of nonfiction that tells a factual story.
Often uses a novelistic structure.
Similar to a documentary in book form.
The study, evaluation, and interpretation of literature.
A form of academic writing.
Looks at the meaning and context of a text.
A short piece of writing on a particular subject.
Can be formal or informal.
Often expresses the author's argument or opinion.
Poetry that does not use rhyme or a regular meter.
Relies on natural speech patterns.
Walt Whitman is a famous example.
A Japanese form of poetry with three lines.
The syllable pattern is 5-7-5.
Often focuses on nature.
A 14-line poem with a specific rhyme scheme.
Often deals with themes of love or beauty.
Shakespeare wrote many famous ones.
A poem or song narrating a story.
Often a folk song passed down through oral tradition.
Often has a simple, rhyming stanza.
A long poem about a heroic figure.
Think 'Beowulf' or 'The Odyssey'.
Often tells the story of a nation or a great war.
A five-line poem with a specific AABBA rhyme scheme.
It is often humorous or nonsensical.
There once was a man from Nantucket...
A dramatic work with exaggerated characters and emotions.
Often features a clear hero, villain, and damsel in distress.
Often accompanied by music.
A genre of comedy with highly improbable situations.
Uses slapstick and absurd humor.
Aims to make the audience laugh.
A genre that uses fictional narratives to critique society.
Similar to a satire, but in a longer format.
'Gulliver's Travels' is a good example.
An imitation of a writer's style for comedic effect.
Often a humorous and exaggerated version of a known work.
Think of 'Scary Movie' for films.
A genre focused on climate change and its impact.
A portmanteau of 'climate' and 'fiction'.
Often explores the future of Earth.
A subgenre inspired by Victorian era technology.
Features steam-powered machinery and aesthetics.
Think of brass goggles and airships.
A genre set in a futuristic, high-tech, low-life society.
Features a combination of advanced technology and societal decay.
Examples include 'Neuromancer' and 'Blade Runner'.
A subgenre of science fiction focused on biotechnology and genetic engineering.
Deals with the implications of bio-hacking.
Often features a dark, gritty tone.
A genre about the end of the world.
Often deals with a major catastrophe.
Examples include 'The Road' and 'I Am Legend'.
A genre set after a major societal collapse.
Focuses on survival and rebuilding.
Often features a desolate world.
A subgenre that focuses on military conflicts in a sci-fi setting.
Features futuristic weapons and combat.
Examples include 'Starship Troopers'.
A subgenre with grand, romantic adventures in space.
Often features sweeping, epic battles and large-scale conflicts.
Similar to 'Star Wars'.
A genre that prioritizes scientific accuracy and detail.
Relies on plausible science and technology.
The opposite of soft science fiction.
A genre that focuses on character and social sciences.
Less emphasis on scientific accuracy.
The opposite of hard science fiction.
A genre where magical elements are a normal part of the real world.
The author presents magic as a matter-of-fact occurrence.
Gabriel Garcia Marquez is a famous author in this style.
A long story about a family's history over several generations.
Often features a large cast of characters.
Norse myths were written in this form.
A coming of age story.
German term for a novel of education.
Traces the protagonist's moral and psychological growth.
A novel with a key.
Fictionalized account of real events and people.
French term for a novel with a key.
A narrative technique that mirrors the flow of thoughts.
Often lacks traditional punctuation and grammar.
James Joyce and Virginia Woolf used this style.
A genre that critiques social issues and injustices.
Often a goal of the author is to provoke thought.
Can be found in both fiction and nonfiction.
A genre for young readers with magical elements.
Examples include 'The Chronicles of Narnia'.
Often teaches a moral lesson.
A book containing a series of poems by one author.
Often organized by theme or chronology.
A way for a poet to showcase a body of work.
A genre that explores and critiques female roles in society.
Often written from a woman's perspective.
Examples include 'The Bell Jar'.
A subgenre that combines romance with gothic elements.
Often set in an eerie, mysterious place.
Features a brooding hero and a brave heroine.
A genre that blends gothic settings with horror elements.
Focuses on suspense and psychological terror.
Examples include 'The Castle of Otranto'.
An umbrella genre for fantasy, sci-fi, and horror.
Explores ideas and possibilities not found in the real world.
Often uses 'what if' scenarios.
A genre where historical events unfold differently.
Asks 'what if' a major event had a different outcome.
Examples include 'The Man in the High Castle'.
A genre describing a perfect society.
Explores an ideal social or political system.
Often a counterpoint to dystopian fiction.
A literary movement from the mid-20th century.
Plays with narrative structure and self-referential writing.
Often includes irony and intertextuality.
A genre that depicts life as it truly is.
Focuses on ordinary people and everyday situations.
A reaction against Romanticism.
A genre that portrays social and environmental forces as destiny.
Similar to realism, but with a more pessimistic view.
Characters are often victims of their circumstances.
A philosophical genre about human freedom and responsibility.
Focuses on individual existence and meaning.
Albert Camus and Jean Paul Sartre are famous writers.
A genre that explores a world without meaning or purpose.
Characters struggle to find logic in their lives.
Often associated with existentialism.
A play with a single, continuous act.
Often shorter than a full-length play.
A popular format for short dramatic works.
A form of performance poetry that is competitive.
Spoken word poetry, often with rhythmic energy.
Judged by the audience.
A work of prose fiction longer than a short story but shorter than a novel.
Examples include 'Of Mice and Men'.
Often contains a single plot line.
The traditional beliefs, customs, and stories of a community.
Passed down through generations.
Includes fairy tales, myths, and legends.
A genre of fantasy with a large-scale plot.
Often includes a hero's journey and a fight for a kingdom.
Examples include 'The Wheel of Time'.
A genre where the magical system has strict rules and consequences.
Magic is treated like a science.
Brandon Sanderson is a key author in this genre.
A genre focused on comfort, low stakes, and gentle narratives.
Often features a found family or wholesome themes.
A reaction to high fantasy.
A genre that incorporates elements of video games.
Characters often have stats, levels, and quests.
Short for 'Literary Role Playing Game'.
A Chinese genre about martial arts heroes.
Often features a fantasy setting and mystical powers.
Examples include 'Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon'.
A Chinese genre about cultivation and immortality.
Characters strive to become divine beings.
Similar to wuxia but with more focus on the supernatural.
A genre focused on spies and international intrigue.
Often involves secret agents and covert operations.
Think of James Bond.
A subgenre of mystery that follows law enforcement.
Shows the step-by-step process of a police investigation.
Popular on television shows like 'CSI'.
A subgenre of thriller set in the legal system.
Often involves lawyers and courtroom drama.
John Grisham is a famous author in this genre.
A subgenre of thriller set in the medical world.
Often involves a doctor or a medical professional.
Examples include works by Robin Cook.
A genre that focuses on the mental and emotional states of characters.
Often involves unreliable narrators and suspense.
The tension is in the mind, not just the action.
A genre focused on high-stakes, fast-paced events.
Protagonists often face physical challenges and danger.
The plot is driven by motion and conflict.
A genre about intelligence agents and espionage.
Often involves high-tech gadgets and double agents.
James Bond is a key figure.
A genre set in a city, often focusing on inner-city life.
Can be a subgenre of drama or romance.
Also known as street lit.
A story that follows a protagonist's journey from childhood to adulthood.
Deals with themes of identity and personal growth.
The German term is 'Bildungsroman'.
A genre set in the American South, with grotesque or bizarre elements.
Often explores themes of decay and poverty.
Associated with authors like William Faulkner.
A genre that blends fantasy, science fiction, and horror.
Often features cosmic horror or strange creatures.
H.P. Lovecraft is a key figure.
A genre that re-imagines ancient myths in a modern context.
Examples include Rick Riordan's 'Percy Jackson'.
Blends mythology with contemporary settings.
A genre that blends mystery with a historical setting.
The crime is solved in a specific time period.
A subgenre of historical fiction.
A genre that combines romance with supernatural elements.
The protagonists are often vampires, werewolves, or ghosts.
Examples include 'Twilight'.
A narrative technique where magical elements appear in an otherwise realistic setting.
The characters accept magic as a normal part of life.
Gabriel Garcia Marquez is a key figure.
A genre that combines romance with a dystopian setting.
The couple must navigate a corrupt society.
Often a subgenre of young adult.
A genre that combines romance with a steampunk setting.
Often features protagonists in Victorian-inspired outfits.
The plot involves steam-powered gadgets.
A genre that focuses on a lighthearted love story.
A mix of romance and humor.
The plot often involves miscommunications and misunderstandings.
A satirical genre that mocks the behavior of a particular social class.
Often involves witty dialogue and romantic entanglements.
Examples include Oscar Wilde's plays.
A play or story with elements of both tragedy and comedy.
Often has a serious theme but a happy ending.
A mix of two genres.
A satirical genre that imitates the style of an epic poem.
It uses heroic language to describe a trivial subject.
Examples include 'The Rape of the Lock'.
A satirical genre that parodies heroic or epic literature.
Uses a grand style to describe insignificant events.
Another name for a mock epic.
A book-length comic book.
Often has a complex plot and serious themes.
A form of sequential art.
A Japanese style of comic book.
Often read from right to left.
Includes a wide range of genres.
A publication that consists of sequential art and stories.
Often features superheroes or fantasy characters.
A shorter form of a graphic novel.
A dramatic work written for performance on stage.
Includes dialogue and stage directions.
Can be a comedy or a tragedy.
The written script for a film.
Includes dialogue, scene descriptions, and camera directions.
A form of dramatic literature.
A book containing a series of short stories by one author.
Often organized by theme or chronology.
A popular format for short fiction.
A collection of literary works by different authors.
Can include stories, poems, or essays.
Often organized by a specific theme or genre.
A personal record of a person's life and thoughts.
Often kept for private use.
A form of nonfiction writing.
A personal record of a person's life and thoughts, written daily.
Similar to a journal, but with a daily focus.
Anne Frank wrote a famous one.
A written message sent from one person to another.
Can be a form of epistolary novel.
A form of communication.
A formal address delivered to an audience.
Can be a work of nonfiction.
Martin Luther King Jr. is famous for one.
A subgenre that explores gender roles in a negative, futuristic society.
A mix of dystopian and feminist fiction.
Examples include 'The Handmaid's Tale'.
A long, heroic story, often about a family or dynasty.
Often set in the past and passed down through generations.
The 'Harry Potter' series can be considered a type of one.
A genre focused on action and excitement.
The protagonist often goes on a journey to a new place.
Examples include 'Treasure Island'.
A genre that combines elements of spy fiction and thrillers.
The protagonist is a spy in a dangerous situation.
James Bond is a key figure.
A genre focused on the armed forces.
Often features a military setting and characters.
Examples include 'The Red Badge of Courage'.
A genre of science fiction with a dark, gritty tone.
Features advanced technology and a decaying society.
The film 'Blade Runner' is a famous example.
A genre of science fiction inspired by the Victorian era.
Features steam-powered machines and technology.
Often has a retro-futuristic aesthetic.
A genre where a story is set in a different world.
The world has different rules or history.
Often a subgenre of fantasy or science fiction.
A genre that combines Westerns with supernatural elements.
Often features cowboys fighting ghosts or monsters.
A mix of two genres.
A subgenre of fantasy with a focus on action.
Often features a warrior protagonist with a magical sidekick.
Think of Conan the Barbarian.
A genre that blends fantasy with a modern city setting.
The magical world coexists with the real one.
Examples include 'The Dresden Files'.
A fantasy subgenre set in a completely fictional world.
Often involves a large-scale conflict between good and evil.
J.R.R. Tolkien's 'Lord of the Rings' is the classic example.
A fantasy subgenre set in the real world.
Magical elements are subtle and not the main focus.
Examples include 'The Secret History'.
A genre that involves supernatural or strange events.
Features ghosts, vampires, and other mystical beings.
Often a subgenre of fantasy or horror.
A genre of literature that combines elements of horror and romance.
Often set in a gloomy, dark setting.
Examples include 'Frankenstein'.
A genre that is set in the past and portrays real historical events.
Often features fictional characters interacting with real figures.
The setting is a key part of the story.
A nonfiction genre that tells the life story of a real person.
The story is written by another author.
A type of nonfiction.
A nonfiction genre where the author writes about their own life.
The writer is also the main character.
A type of nonfiction.
A nonfiction genre that focuses on a specific aspect of a person's life.
More personal and focused than an autobiography.
Examples include 'Eat, Pray, Love'.
A genre of writing that reports on current events.
Can be found in newspapers, magazines, and online.
A form of nonfiction.
A genre of writing that explains and informs.
Used in textbooks, essays, and articles.
A form of nonfiction.
A genre of writing that aims to convince the reader of a certain viewpoint.
Used in essays, speeches, and advertising.
A form of nonfiction.
A genre of writing that uses sensory details to describe a subject.
Used in poetry and travel writing.
A form of nonfiction.
A genre of writing that tells a story.
Can be found in fiction and nonfiction.
A form of writing.
A type of poetry that expresses a speaker's emotions.
Often accompanied by music in ancient times.
A subgenre of poetry.
A 14-line poem with a specific rhyme scheme.
Often focuses on themes of love and beauty.
Shakespeare is famous for writing these.
A long narrative poem about a heroic figure.
Examples include 'The Odyssey' and 'Beowulf'.
A subgenre of poetry.
A five-line poem with a specific AABBA rhyme scheme.

A subgenre of poetry.
A subgenre of fantasy that combines high fantasy with a comedic tone.
Often set in a fictional society with strict rules.
A mix of two genres.
A fantasy subgenre set in a modern city.

A subgenre of science fiction with a dystopian feel.

A genre that portrays a futuristic, oppressive society.

Often aims to provoke social change.

A story that has a hidden meaning, often moral or political.
Characters and events represent abstract ideas.
'Animal Farm' is a well-known example.
A short story, often with talking animals, that teaches a moral.
Associated with Aesop.
The lesson is usually stated at the end.
A short story used to illustrate a moral or spiritual lesson.
Unlike a fable, it usually features human characters.
Examples are found in the Bible.
A children's story featuring magical elements and fantastic creatures.
Often starts with 'Once upon a time...'.
Associated with the Brothers Grimm and Hans Christian Andersen.
A story passed down through generations by word of mouth.
Often reflects a culture's beliefs and values.
Similar to a myth or legend.
A traditional story about gods or heroes.
Explains natural phenomena or a culture's origins.
Greek and Roman stories are common examples.
A story from the past, believed to be true but not proven.
Often about a hero or a supernatural event.
King Arthur is a famous figure in this genre.
A serious play with an unhappy ending.
The protagonist often suffers due to a flaw or fate.
A famous play by Shakespeare is 'Hamlet'.
A play or story with a light, humorous tone and a happy ending.
A famous playwright is Moli√®re.
The opposite of tragedy.
A genre featuring supernatural beings or phenomena.
Includes stories about ghosts, vampires, and werewolves.
Often a subgenre of romance or urban fantasy.
A subgenre set in a city with magical elements.
The magical world coexists with the modern world.
Examples include 'The Dresden Files'.
A genre that blends fantasy with elements of horror.
Often has a somber, gloomy tone.
Examples include 'Berserk' and some works of Neil Gaiman.
A subgenre set in an entirely fictional world.
Often involves an epic struggle between good and evil.
Think 'The Lord of the Rings'.
A subgenre set in the real world with magical elements.
Magic is a small, subtle part of the story.
The opposite of high fantasy.
A genre of prose fiction about a roguish hero.
The protagonist goes through many adventures.
Examples include 'Don Quixote'.
A novel written as a series of documents.
Can be letters, diary entries, or newspaper clippings.
Mary Shelley's 'Frankenstein' uses this technique.
A subgenre of mystery focused on a professional investigator.
The protagonist works to solve a crime.
Sherlock Holmes is a famous example.
A subgenre of detective fiction with a cynical, tough hero.
Often explores the corrupt side of society.
Associated with authors like Raymond Chandler.
A subgenre characterized by a bleak, pessimistic tone.
Often features a flawed protagonist and a femme fatale.
Often overlaps with detective fiction.
A subgenre of mystery with no graphic violence or sex.
Often set in a small, close-knit community.
The detective is typically an amateur.
A nonfiction genre that details real-life crimes.
It is a popular topic for documentaries and podcasts.
Often covers murder, serial killers, and heists.
A brief work of prose fiction.
Shorter than a novella.
Poe and O. Henry are famous practitioners.
A short novel, longer than a short story.
The length is typically between 17,500 and 40,000 words.
'A Christmas Carol' is a classic example.
A very short story.
The word count is typically under 1,000 words.
A form of microfiction.
A genre that uses literary styles to create factual narratives.
Blends personal experience with factual information.
Includes memoir, essay, and travel writing.
A type of nonfiction that tells a factual story.
Often uses a novelistic structure.
Similar to a documentary in book form.
The study, evaluation, and interpretation of literature.
A form of academic writing.
Looks at the meaning and context of a text.
A short piece of writing on a particular subject.
Can be formal or informal.
Often expresses the author's argument or opinion.
Poetry that does not use rhyme or a regular meter.
Relies on natural speech patterns.
Walt Whitman is a famous example.
A Japanese form of poetry with three lines.
The syllable pattern is 5-7-5.
Often focuses on nature.
A 14-line poem with a specific rhyme scheme.
Often deals with themes of love or beauty.
Shakespeare wrote many famous ones.
A poem or song narrating a story.
Often a folk song passed down through oral tradition.
Often has a simple, rhyming stanza.
A long poem about a heroic figure.
Think 'Beowulf' or 'The Odyssey'.
Often tells the story of a nation or a great war.
A five-line poem with a specific AABBA rhyme scheme.
It is often humorous or nonsensical.
There once was a man from Nantucket...
A dramatic work with exaggerated characters and emotions.
Often features a clear hero, villain, and damsel in distress.
Often accompanied by music.
A genre of comedy with highly improbable situations.
Uses slapstick and absurd humor.
Aims to make the audience laugh.
A genre that uses fictional narratives to critique society.
Similar to a satire, but in a longer format.
'Gulliver's Travels' is a good example.
An imitation of a writer's style for comedic effect.
Often a humorous and exaggerated version of a known work.
Think of 'Scary Movie' for films.
A genre focused on climate change and its impact.
A portmanteau of 'climate' and 'fiction'.
Often explores the future of Earth.
A subgenre inspired by Victorian era technology.
Features steam-powered machinery and aesthetics.
Think of brass goggles and airships.
A genre set in a futuristic, high-tech, low-life society.
Features a combination of advanced technology and societal decay.
Examples include 'Neuromancer' and 'Blade Runner'.
A subgenre of science fiction focused on biotechnology and genetic engineering.
Deals with the implications of bio-hacking.
Often features a dark, gritty tone.
A genre about the end of the world.
Often deals with a major catastrophe.
Examples include 'The Road' and 'I Am Legend'.
A genre set after a major societal collapse.
Focuses on survival and rebuilding.
Often features a desolate world.
A subgenre that focuses on military conflicts in a sci-fi setting.
Features futuristic weapons and combat.
Examples include 'Starship Troopers'.
A subgenre with grand, romantic adventures in space.
Often features sweeping, epic battles and large-scale conflicts.
Similar to 'Star Wars'.
A genre that prioritizes scientific accuracy and detail.
Relies on plausible science and technology.
The opposite of soft science fiction.
A genre that focuses on character and social sciences.
Less emphasis on scientific accuracy.
The opposite of hard science fiction.
A genre where magical elements are a normal part of the real world.
The author presents magic as a matter-of-fact occurrence.
Gabriel Garcia Marquez is a famous author in this style.
A long story about a family's history over several generations.
Often features a large cast of characters.
Norse myths were written in this form.
A coming of age story.
German term for a novel of education.
Traces the protagonist's moral and psychological growth.
A novel with a key.
Fictionalized account of real events and people.
French term for a novel with a key.
A narrative technique that mirrors the flow of thoughts.
Often lacks traditional punctuation and grammar.
James Joyce and Virginia Woolf used this style.
A genre that critiques social issues and injustices.
Often a goal of the author is to provoke thought.
Can be found in both fiction and nonfiction.
A genre for young readers with magical elements.
Examples include 'The Chronicles of Narnia'.
Often teaches a moral lesson.
A book containing a series of poems by one author.
Often organized by theme or chronology.
A way for a poet to showcase a body of work.
A genre that explores and critiques female roles in society.
Often written from a woman's perspective.
Examples include 'The Bell Jar'.
A subgenre that combines romance with gothic elements.
Often set in an eerie, mysterious place.
Features a brooding hero and a brave heroine.
A genre that blends gothic settings with horror elements.
Focuses on suspense and psychological terror.
Examples include 'The Castle of Otranto'.
An umbrella genre for fantasy, sci-fi, and horror.
Explores ideas and possibilities not found in the real world.
Often uses 'what if' scenarios.
A genre where historical events unfold differently.
Asks 'what if' a major event had a different outcome.
Examples include 'The Man in the High Castle'.
A genre describing a perfect society.
Explores an ideal social or political system.
Often a counterpoint to dystopian fiction.
A literary movement from the mid-20th century.
Plays with narrative structure and self-referential writing.
Often includes irony and intertextuality.
A genre that depicts life as it truly is.
Focuses on ordinary people and everyday situations.
A reaction against Romanticism.
A genre that portrays social and environmental forces as destiny.
Similar to realism, but with a more pessimistic view.
Characters are often victims of their circumstances.
A philosophical genre about human freedom and responsibility.
Focuses on individual existence and meaning.
Albert Camus and Jean Paul Sartre are famous writers.
A genre that explores a world without meaning or purpose.
Characters struggle to find logic in their lives.
Often associated with existentialism.
A play with a single, continuous act.
Often shorter than a full-length play.
A popular format for short dramatic works.
A form of performance poetry that is competitive.
Spoken word poetry, often with rhythmic energy.
Judged by the audience.
A work of prose fiction longer than a short story but shorter than a novel.
Examples include 'Of Mice and Men'.
Often contains a single plot line.
The traditional beliefs, customs, and stories of a community.
Passed down through generations.
Includes fairy tales, myths, and legends.
A genre of fantasy with a large-scale plot.
Often includes a hero's journey and a fight for a kingdom.
Examples include 'The Wheel of Time'.
A genre where the magical system has strict rules and consequences.
Magic is treated like a science.
Brandon Sanderson is a key author in this genre.
A genre focused on comfort, low stakes, and gentle narratives.
Often features a found family or wholesome themes.
A reaction to high fantasy.
A genre that incorporates elements of video games.
Characters often have stats, levels, and quests.
Short for 'Literary Role Playing Game'.
